John Deere tried to argue in court that farmers didn't actually buy tractors: that there was so much software in the tractor the farmers were only agreeing to a license to use it. Thus, it was illegal for a farmer to get anyone other than John Deere to fix the tractor: _which John Deere still owned_. I don't know if this is resolved or not yet.  Similarly, Tesla *automatically extended the range of their cars* to people in Florida during the hurricane _by unlocking part of the software already present in the car_. Normally, the 'longer range' Tesla was sold as a completely separate car. Turns out, it's all just software, and Tesla can reach in and change things remotely as it wishes. These are worrying developments.

text: Weird - I remember computer classes in highschool in the 80's were about learning BASIC. By the time my son was in highschool in the 2010's they were learning how to configure Cisco servers.   Wonderful - I find myself impressed by how current the school systems (at least in Ottawa) have stayed with technology. What's more, there are many cases around the world where third world countries are leap-frogging the old code and jumping into the new. It does make me wonder though, if it will create new realities for coders in these countries, that may be growing up without the baggage of old code, or old coding ways.   Much like putting two periods after a space, as a carryover from the days of typewriters, I wonder if these places see code and its possibilities differently, unhindered by the frameworks that came before it.

anchor: Coders are people who are willing to work backward to that key press.
text: What I find wonderful here is that it truly opens the doors for digital archaeology, inviting us to examine coding<89>۪s material culture, and seeing how languages like COBOL or FORTRAN may well have created the scaffolding upon which later languages like PYTHON or SWIFT were built. These <89><db><cf>dead<89>۝ languages, in their time, paved the way for new technologies to be built, and for our experiences with them to be crafted through code to produce interfaces for us to interact with and learn new things about our selves and the world we inhabit.   The possibilities for DH are seemingly endless here, as we continually connect seemingly unrelated things, only to find out that they come from a very similar root, forking and converging through iterations and evolutions, leaving in their wake, an ever-changing view of ourselves through technology.

anchor: Just as the keyboard is waiting for a key to be pressed, the computer is waiting for a signal from the keyboard. When one comes down the pike, the computer interprets it and passes it farther into its own interior. <89><db><cf>Here<89>۪s what the keyboard just received<89><db><d3>do with this what you will.<89>۝
text: I find this a little worrying, in that this is not unlike the sequence that one goes through as they scan social media, such as Facebook, waiting to find some way to interact or interject in the views, updates, and opinions being put out there. Even something as mundane as determining where to like or heart something, or whether it is funny or worthy of a <89><db><cf>wow<89>۝ face. I sometimes feel like a keyboard for the aggregated consciousness that underlies the bigger social media platforms. What is worrying is that I sometimes engage with other people<89>۪s lives at a very surface level, only considering the best versions of themselves, that they tend to put up, being carefull to respond in a way that is in line with that best version of myself.   This doesn<89>۪t always work though, and sometimes, like a keyboard that<89>۪s had a drink spilled on it, I write something that is outsid of that persona that I have unwittingly curated over time.

anchor: The turn-of-last-century British artist William Morris once said you can<89>۪t have art without resistance in the materials. The computer and its multifarious peripherals are the materials. The code is the art.
text: I would say that the code is the technique or process. Much like in the way Pollock<89>۪s process/technique was about the motion of his arm and the way in which the paint dripped on the canvas, or Rothko<89>۪s building up of shapes over many layers of paint, code is the process and technique for making the thing into something that is ultimately consumable by those who are not necessarily proficient in the process or technique.

anchor: Apple has always made computers; Microsoft used to make only software (and occasional accessory hardware, such as mice and keyboards), but now it<89>۪s in the hardware business, with Xbox game consoles, Surface tablets, and Lumia phones. Facebook assembles its own computers for its massive data centers.
text: What<89>۪s interesting here is that these companies have embraced the model of the <89><db><cf>WHY<89>۝, in that they have begin to focus more on communicating their values to consumers first, rather than what they produce or how they do it. This allows them to pretty much go into producing anything they want, as long as it aligns with the values of why they exist as an entity. Case in point, Apple is no longer a computer company, they a re a company that makes products that challenge the status quo and provide great user experiences while doing it. So, when we learn that they are making watches, TVs and cars, we do not have to question it, as long as it aligns to their <89><db><cf>why<89>۝. Simon Sinek has done a lot of work on this concept. How great leaders inspire action [See his TED Talk](https://www.ted.com/talks/simon_sinek_how_great_leaders_inspire_action)

anchor: This time you stop yourself. You don<89>۪t want your inquiry to be met by a patronizing sigh of impatience or another explanation about ship dates, Agile cycles, and continuous delivery. Better for now to hide your ignorance. When will it be done? You are learning to accept that the answer for software projects is never.
text: I must admit, the worrying aspect for me with this is that we are continually looking for ways to run and execute on projects, which means that at the tactical levels we are always playing catch-up to learn new ways of doing things, only to find out that at the strategic level, people fell in love with the idea of a process without actually learning it,and yet having the full expectation of realized benefits, when you are only doing a partial implementation. This cycle repeats itself when the new way does not deliver as promised and then a new magic bullet is revealed, and the cycle starts all over again. Meanwhile, nothing gets fully delivered, morale goes down, engagement drops, and  anxiety goes up, as the expectation to deliver on something seems to just build.   This is the trap of technology, things move so fast that we seem to be in perpetual beta, trying to pass ourselves off as being in release.

The widespread use of technology continues to grow and so it's important for me, and everyone. to learn.

What's also interesting about that is that it's a question of perspective. I.e., Someone may see a circle, while another sees a ring, while some else sees a mathematical equation, yet all of these are truths that describe a concept. So, in essence, one could say that the machine could also learn to be creative, but just through a different lens.  What i find weird is the issue of randomness. Random for the sake of random is not ver interesting, but randomness shaped by context seems to be where the more interesting change happens.

It seems oddly meta. It's language within language, to describe a thing hat uses elements of language to make up its own language in a way that we can understand it, so that we can build tools that help us not only communicate in our own language, but in others as well.

anchor: So far we have at least three representations of one letter: the signal from the keyboard; the version in memory; and the lines-and-circles version sketched on the screen. We haven<89>۪t even considered how to store it, or what happens to the letters to the left and the right when you insert an <89><db><cf>a<89>۝ in the middle of a sentence. Or what <89><db><cf>lines and circles<89>۝ mean when reduced to binary data. There are surprisingly many ways to represent a simple <89><db><cf>a.<89>۝ It<89>۪s amazing any of it works at all. anchor: While the entire tech industry has huge gender disparities, the gender gap gets significantly more pronounced when we look specifically at the more prestigious tech departments. E.g: Facebook is 69% male, while their tech team is 85% male. Google overall is 70% male, their tech team 83%. Twitter is 70% male; tech team: 90%.
text: I am always skeptical of numbers as percentages used to make a point. Mainly because my instinct is always to ask, "according to whom" and "compared to what". In this case, I am curious to know whether the skew towards male employees is symptomatic of a bigger issue, not enough women choosing this field in their education and as a careers. The question then is, would the numbers be more balanced if there was more women as part of the pool of resources to choose from?

anchor: The laborers are erased from the narrative, even as we experience their work firsthand when we look at Google Books.
text: What I find interesting about this is how much this concept repeats throughout history. Railroads, highways, high rises, etc., all have a history of these hidden narratives of the people that built them. To some extent, even the iPhone that I am typing this on, has a normalized narrative of f being built in China, as an aggregated, genderless, faceless persona.   What is worrying to me is that this seems to be part of a larger notion of consumers compromising values and to some extent certain ethics, opting for convenience. Security and privacy of personal information would also fall into this.   In the long run, what will we accept as OK, be cause we gain more benefit than the cost to our humanity? That's also worrying.

text: The dependence on users, and the fact that they can become co-developers reminds me of actor network theory. The code in this case needs to adopted by users in order to move from a weak concept to a strong/dominant one. The users can be considered as actants in the development of what Steven Ward refers to as an encompassing network. As Raymond highlights, users can lead to the development and improvement of the code.
